content.description: Climb nicely-spaced edges on a vertical face to gain a ledge.  Transition on to the tower proper on slabbier terrain, pulling a small bulge to finish.  Surprisingly enjoyable climbing and better than it looks.
content.location: Far left side of Franklin's Tower (or far right side of Gotham City).

content.description: Start at a crack/seam right of the arete.  This leads to a long leftward span move (crux) followed by another long move to gain the horizontal/ledge.  Move left again up a steeper face section, then into the handcrack which is followed to the top.  Good climbing and well bolted.
Sustained thin and technical climbing punctuated by powerful, large moves off of less than desirable footholds.  Considered solid for the grade.
content.protection: Bolts.  Fixed draws on all bolts besides the first as of 4/26/08. (Don't steal 'em!)

content.description: Hard climbing starts directly off the ground and doesn't let up until past halfway. Intricate yet powerful bouldery moves with poor feet on small holds. Feels harder than 13c to me.
content.protection: 12 bolts. All draws are fixed except for the first.
content.location: A fixed rope up and to the right of Steel Monkey leads you around the corner to a nice belay ledge for this route. You will pass the belay for Elemonkey (also given 13c in the guide) on the way.

content.description:
If this doesn't catch your eye on the approach, you might not be alive.

This route starts wide (maybe 7") and gets gradually wider stopping at about 10". If you're lucky you can squeeze inside for the top out, if not prepare for some slightly overhanging chicken wings.

Very reminiscent of Pratt's Crack though it's slightly harder; if it was as long it would be just as good. Rock quality is excellent, and just enough edges to rest on to keep it in the 5.9 range.

Fairly easy to toprope after leading Franklin's Frosty Funeral or bring yer big gear and get it on lead. If leading you can either finish up at the top of the wide (bring cordelette to build anchor, no bolts) and scramble/downclimb the back, or for TR laps probably better to continue straight up and use the anchors at the top of Franklin's Frosty Funeral (10c)
content.protection:
Blue big bros fit well (and even a green, at spots), I pushed a Merlin 8 (9" cam) but it was *very* tipped out toward the top.

Probably a 12" cam would be better for a pusher, but as long as you have some blue bros for backup you should be good.
content.location: Visible on the approach as the widest crack you can see, directly across from the bottom of the Upper Gorge approach trail

content.description: Another hard line that climbs an aesthetic rounded arete. Unfortunately the rock is not of the best quality.
content.location: It starts on the obvious block to the right of Steel Monkey.

content.description: Close to three stars.  Crack climb up a steep corner, mostly hands with at least one move of OW, for eight bolts.  At this point, the natural line continues up the corner past a large bird nest and loose blocks (~5.8, traumatic), but the route cuts left onto an exposed, hard-for-the-grade arete.
content.location: Starting around the base of Tower Line, scrambled up and right for about 100' to the SECOND set of anchors (the first is the start of Steel Monkey).  Cruella follows an obvious south and right facing corner.

content.description: The vertical arete right next to the river.  A tricky start leads up to the sharp arete section.  The business begins here.  Balancey, technical moves lead up the arete, leading to a hard move to gain good edges which are followed to the top. Very good climbing on quality rock.
